resources.string: Preloaded Example Data: Mixed 520 cm mast with Gastra Bottom and Amex Top

Useful Info
 (Source Unifiber and Tushingham)
 The key points you have to take into account when choosing a mast are:
 1. Flex 
 2. Stiffnes (IMCS) 
 3. Carbon fiber percentage

Curvature (Flex)
 Curvature, aka FLEX, represents the bent shape of the mast when loaded by the rigged sail. Normally the cross sections of the typical mast decrease starting from the bottom tapering toward the top. The larger cross sections at the bottom determine higher stiffness and, as a consequence, less bending of the lower part of the mast with respect to the upper part of it. The FLEX parameter represents the amount of difference between the deformation of the upper part and that of the lower part of a mast. The industry standard terms describing windsurfing mast bend curves are:
 0-6 = Hard top
 7-9 = Hard Top/Constant Curve
 10-12 = Constant Curve
 13-15 =Constant Curve/Flex top
 16-18 = Flex Top
 19-21 = Flex Top/Super Flex Top
 22+ = Super Flex Top
 The higher the number the more flexible the mast is in the upper half relative to the bottom. The Flex Top masts, more flexible near the top, are build following different criteria with respect to the Hard Top, stiffer near the top.
 FLEX is calculated as a percentage ratio between:
 - the difference between the deformations taken respectively at 1/4 of L from the TOP and the Bottom;
 - the deformation of the mast in its middle;
 when the mast is loaded with a weight of 30Kg in its middle.

Stiffness (IMCS)\n
Stiffness, commonly referred to as IMCS (Indexed Mast Check System), is an indication of how much a mast bends when it is loaded. Normally the IMCS varies from 6 to 38. The higher the IMCS the stiffer the mast. Most of the mast brands usually adopt standard values of IMCS with reference to standard lengths. For instance often 400cm masts have IMCS 19, whereas 430cm masts have IMCS 21 and 490cm masts have IMCS 29. It is easy to realize that these different masts of different lengths, have all a tipical MCS of 25 (which in turn shows that almost any mast has the same deformation in the middle).\n
The numerical value of the IMCS results from the ratio between: - the length of the mast raised to the power of three; - the product of 460 (or 465) squared and the deformation in the middle when the mast is loaded with a weight of 30kh in its middle.

Carbon percentage content\n The content of carbon fiber (with respect to the concomitant content of different kinds of other fibers such as glass) varies usually between 30 and 100. The higher the content of carbon fiber, the more reactive and lighter the rig will be which, in turn, will result in a better control. As a result, the sails performances will improve when masts with high carbon percentage are used.
